title: Lab to determine coefficient of friction

content.question:
Read each part carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

A group of students are instructed to perform an experiment to determine the coefficient of kinetic friction, <math alttext="mu sub k" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, between a box and a rough horizontal surface. They are expected to find <math alttext="mu sub k" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> by plotting their data in a graph. The students have access to equipment commonly found in a high school physics laboratory, but the experiment must use the setup shown above. The setup includes a box of mass <math alttext="uppercase M" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> sliding down a smooth plane that is inclined at an angle <math alttext="theta" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> above the horizontal in section <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The box continues sliding onto an initially smooth horizontal surface. The horizontal surface then becomes rough, with a coefficient of kinetic friction <math alttext="mu sub k" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> as shown in section <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Assume that the friction is negligible between the box and the plane in section <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and between the box and the smooth section of the horizontal surface, and that the box makes a smooth transition from section <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to the horizontal surface.

(a) Identify each quantity to be measured, the symbol used to represent that quantity, and the equipment that would be used to measure the quantity.

A group of students are instructed to perform an experiment to determine the coefficient of kinetic friction, <math alttext="mu sub k" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, between a box and a rough horizontal surface. They are expected to find <math alttext="mu sub k" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> by plotting their data in a graph. The students have access to equipment commonly found in a high school physics laboratory, but the experiment must use the setup shown above. The setup includes a box of mass <math alttext="uppercase M" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> sliding down a smooth plane that is inclined at an angle <math alttext="theta" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> above the horizontal in section <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. The box continues sliding onto an initially smooth horizontal surface. The horizontal surface then becomes rough, with a coefficient of kinetic friction <math alttext="mu sub k" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> as shown in section <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Assume that the friction is negligible between the box and the plane in section <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and between the box and the smooth section of the horizontal surface, and that the box makes a smooth transition from section <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>I</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> to the horizontal surface.

(a) Identify each quantity to be measured, the symbol used to represent that quantity, and the equipment that would be used to measure the quantity.

(b) Describe the procedure to be used to determine the coefficient of kinetic friction, <math alttext="mu sub k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, between the box and the flat rough surface in section <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Provide enough detail so that another student could replicate the experiment, including any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty. As needed, use the symbols defined in part (a) above.

(c) Which quantities (raw data or calculated from the data) would be graphed on the vertical and horizontal axes to produce a graph that could be used to determine the coefficient of kinetic friction, <math alttext="mu sub k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> ?

(d) Describe which information from the graph described in part (c) would be used and how it would be used to determine the coefficient of kinetic friction, <math alttext="mu sub k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(e) Another group of students argue that if this experiment were to be repeated on the Moon, the determined value for the coefficient of kinetic friction <math alttext="mu sub k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> between the box and the surface would be different. If the procedure and analysis described in part (b) through part (d) were to be repeated on the Moon, would the result for the coefficient of kinetic friction <math alttext="mu sub k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>μ</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>k</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> be greater than, less than, or equal to the coefficient of kinetic friction obtained on Earth?

skill.text: 3.A: Create experimental procedures that are appropriate for a given scientific question.
